a1: Strength is calculated using entropy (bits of randomness), character diversity (4 types), length, and checks against common passwords and patterns.
q2: Is my password sent to a server?
a2: No. All analysis happens locally in your browser. Your password never leaves your device.
a3: A strong password is at least 12 characters long, uses uppercase, lowercase, digits, and symbols, and avoids common words or patterns.
a4: Entropy measures randomness in bits. Higher entropy means more possible combinations, making the password harder to crack. 80+ bits is considered very strong.
q5: Why does it flag common passwords?
a5: Common passwords appear in breach databases and are the first ones attackers try. Even a long common password provides zero real security.
